attributes.title: Parenthood Identities Predict Conspicuous Consumption
attributes.description: This project is examining the effect of parenting motivations on products that enhance social image.

q2.value:
H1) Parenting motivations increase the desire for aesthetic products (vs. functional products).  
H2) H1 will be mediated by the perception that one's own social image impacts the social image of a child (proximal mediator) and increased impression management concerns (distal mediator).

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Participants will first view a slideshow priming parenting motivations or a control slideshow where they think about their everyday life. Afterwards, participants will make a selection between a functional sweater and an aesthetically pleasing, less functional sweater. Then, participants will answer questions regarding the mediators and answer questions checking the manipulation of the videos. Finally, they will answer demographic questions.

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to the two slideshows - the parenting motivation prime vs. the control.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect data using TurkPrime. Participants will be told that they are completing a study on perception. They will be paid $.35. Participants will be allowed to complete this study as long as they have not completed other studies that have been apart of the same project.

q11.value: We will recruit 240 participants through TurkPrime.

q12.value: A power analysis based on earlier data suggested that we needed at least 240 participants.

q13.value: TurkPrime occasionally includes a few extra participants. Therefore, our stopping rule will be to stop when TurkPrime states that the study has been completed.

question.value: We will manipulate parenting motivation through a slideshow. Half the participants will receive this slideshow, while the other half will receive a control slideshow where they think about their everyday life.

We will measure the following: 
1) Desire for the dependent variable product - preference between a functional sweater and an aesthetic (less functional) sweater
2) Feelings that their own social image impacts the social image of a child
3) Concern for impression management
4) Manipulation check of video (i.e., feelings of being a parent).
5) Perception that the aesthetic product is seen as enhancing image and perception that the aesthetic product is seen as enhancing warmth.
6) Demographic variables (gender, age, income, parenthood status).

Feelings of being a parent (4 items; manipulation check) will be averaged into one variable. Additionally, the measures for the impression management concerns (3 items; distal mediator) will be combined into one item via creating a mean.
We will use an ANOVA to test the main effect. We will also use Hayes Process Macro to test the mediation model and the direct effect. 5000 bootstraps will be used.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The Hayes Process Analysis will use confidence intervals to test the efficacy of the mediation.

q20.value: No participants will be excluded unless they skip the dependent variable. Outliers will be left in the analyses. We will not include any awareness checks.

q21.value: We will use participants' data except for the missing items, which will be left missing. The only exception will be if they skip the dependent variable, in which case they will be excluded from all analyses.

H1) Parenting motivations increase the desire for aesthetic products (vs. functional products).  
H2) H1 will be mediated by the perception that one's own social image impacts the social image of a child (proximal mediator) and increased impression management concerns (distal mediator).

Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

attributes.title: Bouletic Reasoning
attributes.description: What sorts of inferences do people draw when they reason about people's desires? For instance, if John learns that Mary wants to go for a drive, does he infer that she is not already driving? This inference seems intuitive, yet there is not much discussion about this kind of inference, let alone empirical research on it. Theoretical discussion about desires generally focus on the desires expressed by the verb "want", and the discussion is centered on how the expressed desires are related to the attitude holder's beliefs and on what the relevant set is that the desired objects are compared to (see e.g. Heim 1992, Villalta 2008, Rubinstein 2012). We thus conduct experiments to test the extent to which people draw this inference with desire verbs.

q1.value: Bouletic Reasoning: Inferences about desire verbs' complements' falsity

q3.value:
We want to examine whether people interpret the complement of a desire verb to represent a possibility that is not currently true. Take the following sentence. 

Jiro wants Susan to be a doctor. 

The complement is "Susan to be a doctor". Our proposal is that people interpret the possibility this represents to be false.

q4.value:
Our experiment will use 4 types of verbs: 

i) desire verbs: 'want', 'wish', 'hope';
ii) negative verbs: 'refuse', 'fail', 'decline';
iii) appearance verbs: 'seem', 'appear', 'claim'; and 
iv) resultative verbs: 'manage', 'happen', 'turn out'.

Each verb will be used in a sentence pair of the following template: 

Miriam [VERB] to own a Porsche. 
Miriams currently owns a Porsche. 

Participants will mark the second sentence along a 7-point Likert scale of 'definitely false' to 'definitely true'. 
 
Our hypothesis is that desire verbs will pattern like negative verbs, meaning that participants will rate the sentences with negative verbs and desire verbs as 'definitely false'. We predict that sentences in pairs with appearance verbs will be rated as 'neither true nor false', and that ratings of 'true' will be given to sentences with resultative verbs.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The experiment is within-subjects. All participants will rate the truth/falsity of all the second sentences in all 12 sentence pairs of the study.

q9.value: Each sentence pair will randomly be assigned the name of a person (either male or female) to serve as the subject of the sentence. The sentence pairs will be presented in a randomized order, varying randomly for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: All subjects will be recruited using Amazon Mechanical Turk, and will be reimbursed for participating in the study. We will not use data collected from any participant who does not indicate that English is their native language.

q13.value: We will run the experiment on 50 unique participants.

q14.value:
We ran a power analysis using the "pwr" package in R, assuming a power of .95 and a large effect size (d = .50).

pwr.t.test(d = .50, sig.level = .05, power = .95, type = c("paired"))

    Paired t test power calculation 

             n = 53.94061
             d = 0.5
     sig.level = 0.05
         power = 0.95
   alternative = two.sided

question.value:
The independent variable in this study is the type of verb used in the stimuli: the negative verbs, resultative verbs, and appearance verbs form the control sentences; the desire verbs form the experimental sentences. 

The dependent variable is participants' ratings of the sentences as true or false on a Likert scale from -3 (definitely false) to +3 (definitely true).
see above
We will evaluate the data using a Wilcoxon signed rank test, to see whether participant responses are a function of the verb type.

attributes.title: Interest Groups and Political Communication, Study 2.1
attributes.description: Interest groups have become important communicators in political communication. Yet, we know very little about the effects of their interventions. While persuasion research stresses that prior attitudes toward senders, such as credibility assessments, are decisive for acceptance or rejection of messages, it is not clear whether this is also true for interest group communication, given their typically low public profiles. In this, the first of two studies, we examine public profiles and credibility assessments of 10 German interest groups and parties represented in parliament.

q1.value: Alexander Wuttke, Andreas Jungherr, Matthias	Mader, Harald Schoen

q2.value:
H2a: Respondents are less likely to express credibility assessments for interest groups than for political parties.
H2b: Respondents are less certain about their credibility assessments of interest groups than about their credibility assessments of political parties.

We consider it an open empirical question whether the patterns expected in H2a, H2b also hold for the small set of interest groups with relatively high public profiles (measured by relative media presence).

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Main interest of this study is observational: comparison of credibility-related assessments of different types of interest groups and political parties.

We compare following types of political actors:

Interest Groups with relatively high public profile (assessed by relative media presence in the previous year):
- Greenpeace: 
- Deutsche Umwelthilfe: 
- Naturschutzbund Deutschland (NABU):
- Bund für Umwelt und Naturschutz Deutschland (BUND)
- Germanwatch: 

Interest Groups with relatively low public profile (assessed by media presence in the previous year):
- Deutscher Naturschutzring
- NaturFreunde Deutschland
- Naturschutzform Deutschland
- MUNA: Mensch, Umwelt-, Natur- und Artenschutz
-  Bundesdeutsche Arbeitskreis für Umweltbewusstes Management (B.A.U.M.)

Political Parties: 
-	CDU/CSU;
-	SPD;
-	AfD;
-	FDP;
-	DIE LINKE; 
-	Bündnis 90/Die Grünen.

This study also contains an experimental module that serves as a pre-test for a follow-up study and which is not part of this pre-registration.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will analyze from all participants provided by Respondi who completed the questionnaire and who do not qualify as straightliners on the matrix questions (see pre-registered analysis syntax).
not applicable (observational study)

See Questionnaire attached.

Main variables of interest:
Credibility Assessments of Political Parties and Interest Groups#
Certainty of these Credibility Assessments

Unweighted mean indices were computed across indicators using all non-missing indicators for each respondent
1) of share of provided credibility-assessments and 
2) of level of credibility certainty, 
separately for political parties, interest groups with high public profile and interest groups with low public profile.


****** AVAILABILITY OF CREDIBILITY ASSESSMENTS

*** Share of low profile interest groups for which a respondent did not provide a substantive response
* Missing if all indicators are missing
egen cred_low_profile_abs = rowmean(cred_naturschutzring_abs_d cred_naturfreunde_abs_d cred_naturschutzforum_abs_d cred_muna_abs_d cred_arbeitskreis_abs_d)

*** Share of parties for which a respondent did not provide a substantive response
* Missing if all indicators are missing
egen cred_parties_abs = rowmean(cred_union_abs_d cred_spd_abs_d cred_afd_abs_d cred_fdp_abs_d cred_left_abs_d cred_greens_abs_d)


****** CERTAINTY

*** low profile interest groups: average certainty of credibility assessment (if credibility assessment was provided)
egen cert_low_profile_abs = rowmean(cert_naturschutzring cert_naturfreunde cert_naturschutzforum cert_muna cert_arbeitskreis)

*** parties: average certainty of credibility assessment (if credibility assessment was provided)
egen cert_parties_abs = rowmean(cert_union cert_spd cert_afd cert_fdp cert_left cert_greens)

We will make use of two different strategies, formal and descriptive, to test the expected differences in the distribution of credibility assessments regarding interest groups on political parties.

Formally, we conduct null hypothesis significance tests using simple t tests to compare the frequency of unavailable credibility assessments and levels of the certainty of credibility assessments between low profile interest groups and political parties. For these comparisons, we will rely on aggregated group-level indices, that represent averages of the indicators of single actors of interesting groups of low public profile and political parties.


*** H2a: Respondents are less likely to express credibility assessments for interest groups than for political parties

* NHST - Simple test (one-sided, diff > 0 )
ttest cred_low_profile_abs == cred_parties_abs   


*** H2b: Respondents are less certain about their credibility assessments of interest groups than about their credibility assessments of political parties.

* NHST - Simple test (one-sided, diff < 0 )
ttest cert_low_profile_abs == cert_parties_abs  


As these formal tests only entail null hypothesis significance testing, we consider these group-level comparisons of low profile interest groups with political parties as minimal tests of the hypotheses. 

In addition to these formal tests, we will show the distribution of the credibility-related attitudes for each interest groups. These descriptive analyses of the distribution will therefore also allow to assess the magnitude of the expected differences between the types of political actors.

q18.value:
*H2a: Respondents are less likely to express credibility assessments for interest groups than for political parties. 
*(Higher frequency of absent credibility assessments of IGs than of parties)
*(We consider it an open empirical question whether the patterns expected in H2a, H2b also hold for the small set of interest groups with relatively high public profiles (measured by relative media presence)


*** Dummy: Provided credibilty assessment or not
foreach var of varlist cred_greenpeace cred_umwelthilfe cred_nabu cred_bund cred_germanwatch cred_naturschutzring cred_naturfreunde cred_naturschutzforum cred_muna cred_arbeitskreis cred_union cred_spd cred_afd cred_fdp cred_left cred_greens {
		
		gen `var'_abs_d = cond(`var'==.n | `var'==.c, 1, 0)	 // 1 if clicked on "cannot assess" or when questionnaire page was seen but no response was provided
		replace `var'_abs_d = . if `var' == .					// do not consider respondents who have MV for reasons other than not providing a substantive response on the relevant item although they saw it
}

q19.value: One-tailed significance tests in the direction of the pre-registered hypotheses. Alpha=0.05

q20.value:
** Straightliners will be dropped.
** Straightliners are defined as those respondents who provided identical answers to all items on either the frequency battery or the credibility of parties battery (where at least some differences are to be expected between items)



*frequency battery
gen straight_line_1 = 	freq_greenpeace ==  freq_umwelthilfe & ///
						freq_greenpeace ==  freq_nabu	& ///
						freq_greenpeace ==  freq_bund	& ///
						freq_greenpeace ==  freq_germanwatch	& ///
						freq_greenpeace ==  freq_naturfreunde & ///
						freq_greenpeace ==  freq_naturschutzring & ///
						freq_greenpeace ==  freq_naturschutzforum & ///
						 !missing(freq_greenpeace)

						        
*credibility parties						
gen straight_line_2 = 	cred_union == cred_spd	& 	///
							cred_union == cred_afd	& 	///
							cred_union == cred_fdp	& 	///
							cred_union == cred_left	& 	///
							cred_union == cred_greens	&  ///
							!missing(cred_union)
							

							
*Drop Straightliners
drop if straight_line_1 == 1 | straight_line_2 == 1

q21.value: Listwise deletion. No procedures for value imputation will be used.

q23.value: Based on synthetic survey data that was generated before data collection, the attached analysis syntax contains necessary data wrangling steps and the statistical analysis.

registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

attributes.title: Survey of substance use in university students
attributes.description: This is a protocol for an online survey being led by three psychology undergraduate students for their respective dissertations. Each student is overseeing a separate research question: 1) What motivates UK university students to drink different units of alcohol in different locations? 2) What motivates the use of three illicit drugs (cocaine, cannabis, MDMA) in the UK student population? and 3) Can UK students’ understandings of the strengths and risks of MDMA be improved by viewing a drug safety information campaign?

attributes.title: DARVO-SF
attributes.description: Data collected from General Survey in 2019 & 2020 as well as online (prolific.ac) to create a DARVO-SF

copyright_holders: Melissa L. Barnes & Jennifer J. Freyd

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: DARVO-SF: The primary goal of this study is to create the DARVO-SF. We distributed an online survey to collect data about participants' experiences of confrontation. Participants provided information about the wrongdoing that was the focus of the confrontation and psychological distress after the confrontation. Secondary goals involve looking for correlates.

other.value: Data collection has been completed for this study at the time of this preregistration. This was a survey study – not an experiment. There are no conditions, only a set of survey measurement instruments. Importantly, the data have NOT been accessed by the researchers. We do not plan to access and analyze the data until after we complete this preregistration for our data analysis plan.

sample.value:
We used Hatcher’s (1994) guideline that the number of participants should equal five times the number of items included in the exploratory factor analysis. The DARVO-LF has 72 items; thus, our goal was to recruit 360 participants in the non-university sample. Ideally, the university sample would have a similar number of participants.  

Data collection is complete and our non-university sample size is N = 389 and our university sample size is N = 354.

analyses.value:
The data will be quantitatively analyzed to address the two aims of this study. Prior to addressing the main aims and hypotheses of this study, we will complete a correlational analysis to determine if prior trauma history (measured through the BBTS) or the type of confrontation should be accounted for in subsequent data analysis. 

Aim 1. To create the DARVO-SF we will conduct psychometric analyses, including factor analysis, to extract a small set of items that reliably measure DARVO. 

We collected two different samples: one university sample and one non-university sample. The non-university sample will be randomly split in half. One-half of the sample will be used to conduct an exploratory factor analysis and the second half of the non-university sample will be used to conduct a confirmatory factor analysis. We will then use the university sample to conduct a second confirmatory factor analysis, using the DARVO-SF that was created from the non-university data.

Aim 2. To address the second study aim, we will conduct correlational analyses to test associations between DARVO-LF, DARVO-SF, type of confrontation, and trauma symptoms. These analyses will be conducted separately on both datasets.

Aim 3. We will conduct analyses to explore the role of gender and marginalized group identity (e.g., race, sexual orientation, etc.) on experiences of DARVO during confrontation. We will compare these results between the DARVO-LF and DARVO-SF to ensure the short form provides similar results compared to the original, longer scale.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from data analysis if they did not correctly answer at least two of the three attention check items. Participants will also be excluded if they did not complete at least 75% (i.e., 56 items) of the DARVO-LF measure.

dependent.value:
This is a survey study and all measures were presented to all participants.  Most of the measures have been used in prior studies.  The only new measure was the Experiences with Confrontation measure. The key dependent variable in this study is psychological distress and was measured by the Trauma Symptom Checklist - 40 (Briere & Runtz, 1989; Briere, 1996). We are interested in how the created DARVO-SF is correlated with psychological distress after a confrontation. Participants completed the following measures:

1. Brief Betrayal Trauma Survey (Goldberg & Freyd, 2006; modified for this study) - Measure with 4 items to document participants’ interpersonal trauma history.

2. Experiences with Confrontation – Measure with five items designed for this protocol to document participants’ confrontation experiences with friends and family. Participants reported different types of confrontations they have initiated with friends or family. Prior to completing the DARVO Questionnaire, participants chose one of the confrontations they reported either in this measure or in the modified Brief Betrayal Trauma Survey to focus on when they completed the DARVO Questionnaire. 

3. DARVO Questionnaire - Standard measure with 72 items documenting participants’ experiences of wrongdoer’s responses to victim’s confrontation (Harsey, Zurbriggen, & Freyd, 2017).

4. Trauma Symptom Checklist – 40 (Briere & Runtz, 1989; Briere, 1996) – Standard measure with 40 items to document psychological symptoms.

5. Demographic information – Eight standard demographic questions (e.g., age, gender, religion, etc.). Two additional questions specifically related to participants’ marginalized identities.

6. Attention check questions – Three items were distributed throughout the survey to ensure participants are paying attention to each item.

conditions.value: This is a survey study. Everyone got the same survey; thus, there is one condition in this study. There are no experimental conditions in this study.

hypothesis.value:
The current study has three aims. 

The primary aim is to create a DARVO-Short Form (DARVO-SF) measure that will allow researchers to measure DARVO reactions in a more efficient manner. We hypothesize that the data will provide a structure of 18 or fewer items that map on to four factors: Deny, Attack, Reverse Victim and Offender, and Apology. 

A second aim is to test associations between DARVO-LF, DARVO-SF, type of confrontation, and psychological distress. We hypothesize there will be a strong, positive correlation between DARVO-LF and DARVO-SF. We also hypothesize there will be a positive correlation between DARVO-SF and psychological distress, similar to the associations established in the literature between DARVO-LF and psychological distress.  

The third aim is to further examine the role of gender and marginalized identities on experiences on DARVO. We hypothesize that, regardless of confrontation type, women and marginalized people will report more instances of DARVO during confrontation as measured by both the DARVO-LF and DARVO-SF.

The current study has three aims. 

The primary aim is to create a DARVO-Short Form (DARVO-SF) measure that will allow researchers to measure DARVO reactions in a more efficient manner. attributes.title: Fakeness by Repetition Effect.
attributes.description: Experiment on the Fakeness by Repetition Effect.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

attributes.title: Gratitude present bias
attributes.description: This study investigates whether gratitude reduces impatience for monetary and environmental outcomes. Contributors: Lina Koppel, Beate Undén, Daniel Västfjäll.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: We might supplement with additional analyses in which we investigate order effects (i.e., whether the monetary or environmental scenario was presented first) and control for factors such as age and gender. Furthermore, if there are cases where indifference points cannot be determined from the binary choice scale or cases where participants' choices indicate negative discounting (e.g., choosing $230 in 1 year over $250 immediately, or switching from preferring the immediate outcome to preferring the future outcome rather than the other way around), then we will perform sensitivity analyses to try to account for this. For example, we might repeat the analyses while excluding participants with inconsistent choice behavior or negative discount factors. We might also investigate whether responses on the free-response question correlate well with responses on the binary choice scale among participants whose responses allowed us to determine an indifference point from the binary choice scale. Finally, as a manipulation check, we will perform independent samples t-tests on each of the three manipulation check items, comparing the gratitude condition to the neutral condition.

analyses.value: For each domain (monetary and environmental), we will perform a two-tailed independent samples t-test to compare discount factors across the two conditions (gratitude vs. neutral). We will then perform a 2x2 ANOVA to compare effects across domains.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analysis if they do not complete all tasks in the study or if it is not possible to determine their indifference point (and, hence, discount factor) in the temporal discounting task.

dependent.value:
Impatience will be measured using a temporal discounting task from Hardisty and Weber (2009), in which participants make a series of choices between immediate and future outcomes (e.g., a choice between receiving $250 today or receiving $270 in 1 year). They also answer a free-response question, in which they fill in the future value that would make them indifferent between the immediate and future outcome. All participants will respond to two scenarios: one monetary gain scenario and one environmental gain scenario, in counterbalanced order.

The point at which participants switch from preferring the future outcome to preferring the immediate outcome will be used as their indifference point (using the mean between the future values of the two options). If an indifference point cannot be determined from the binary choice scale (e.g., if a participant has multiple switching points or if a participant maxes out the scale), the indifference point will be determined using the free-response question. Following Hardisty and Weber (2009), we will then calculate each participant's discount factor k in each of the two domains (monetary and environmental) using the hyperbolic formula V = A/(1 + kD), where V is the present value, A is the future amount [number of days], D is the delay (in years), and k is a fitted parameter.

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions: gratitude or a neutral feeling state. In the gratitude condition, participants will be asked to write at least five sentences about a situation in which they experienced gratitude. In the neutral condition, participants will do the same but about a normal day in their life. Following this task, all participants indicate on a 5-point scale (1=not at all, 5=very  much) how well their current emotional state is captured by each of the three feelings grateful, appreciative, thankful. These items will be used as a manipulation check.

hypothesis.value:
1. Gratitude reduces impatience for monetary gains (conceptually replicating findings from DeSteno et al., 2014).
2. Gratitude reduces impatience for environmental gains.
